block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''ROMEO AND JULIET,'' a 90-minute production featuring masks, music and pageantry by the Lite Theater Company staged in Brooklyn's Prospect Park at the Tennis House (enter the park at Ninth Street and Prospect Park Drive and cross the West Drive), amid the open-air classical architecture of steps and columns. Audience members can bring blankets or folding chairs. For all ages. Saturdays at 4 p.m. and Sundays and Wednesdays at 7 p.m. Through Aug. 19. Free. Information: (212) 414-7773.

''THE UGLY DUCKLING,'' a musical version of the fairy tale by Debra Kaye, with lyrics by Brenda Bell, by Literally Alive at the Hitchcock-Rockefeller Auditorium, Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue at 53rd Street. For ages 3 to 8. Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m., with art workshops (children will create decorations for the stage) at 1. Through Aug. 13. Tickets: $15 (summer special, 2 tickets for the price of 1); $5 workshop fee. Group rates for 20 and more. Reservations: (212) 866-5170.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' a series of selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

''BATTERY BOOKWORMS,'' storytelling by Cecilia Carson featuring ''Froggie Went A-Courting'' and ''The Tooth Fairy Is Broke,'' tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, on the Grand Staircase, West Street, between Liberty and Vesey Streets. Free. Information: (212) 945-2600.

''BEADS, BODY AND SOUL: ART AND LIGHT IN THE YORUBA UNIVERSE,'' an exhibition presented jointly by the Studio Museum in Harlem (through Sept. 17) and the Museum for African Art (through Aug. 27) explores 1,000 years of beaded arts in the Yoruba culture. The Studio Museum in Harlem will present a bead-making workshop tomorrow at 10:30 a.m, for children 6 and older who will create ''story bracelets,'' at 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, extension 230. Free with admission; suggested donation is $5 for adults; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. The Museum for African Art will present an interactive storytelling session tomorrow at 1 p.m., at 593 Broadway, SoHo. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly. Call to reserve space for all activities. Information: (212) 966-1313, extension 125.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY. Two workshops tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m.: Fly-tying demonstrations and fish identification, at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370. All ages. Also, learning about mammals and reptiles in a crafts workshop, at the Dairy, midpark at 65th Street, (212) 794-6564. For ages 6 and older. Free.

CHINATOWN SUMMER FESTIVAL, Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Bayard Street, between Elizabeth and Baxter Streets, activities include dance and music performances, origami workshops, face painting, temporary tattoos and a technology pavilion. Free. Information: (212) 979-1108, extension 106.

FIRE SAFETY SHOW. Important safety tips for children 4 to 10 will be dispensed along with magic tricks, comedy and audience participation, today at 4 p.m. at Queens Village Branch Library, 94-11 217 Street. Free. Information: (718) 776-6800.

''HBO KID FLICKS STUDIO TOUR,'' at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, 212 West 83rd Street, Tuesday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., is a mobile, interactive learning exhibition, filled with touch-screen IMac stations designed to motivate young filmmakers. As a prelude to the exhibition, tomorrow and Sunday throughout the day there will be screenings of 10 short films in the Time Warner Media Center written, directed and produced by youngsters 8 to 18, featured on HBO Family's series ''30 by 30: Kid Flicks.'' Museum hours through Labor Day: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; infants under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton, will be home to the Bruce C. Heezen, the Navy's newest oceanographic survey ship, and will be available for tours today from noon to 3 p.m. and tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. Also tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., demonstrations by U.S. Coast Guard cutters involving an HH-65 Dolphin helicopter, drug dogs and rescue gear. Events are free on the pier. Information: (212) 245-0072.

''JUDY! JUDY! JUDY!'' Vincente Minnelli's ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' (1944), set in 1903 during the World's Fair, is part of the Judy Garland film series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, tomorrow and Sunday at 11 a.m. Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center. Tickets: $3. Information: (212) 875-5601.
''MAGIC BOB.'' Magic tricks, comedy, storytelling and mind-reading with Bob McEntee, today at 4 p.m. at Flushing Library, 41-17 Main Street, Queens. Free. Information: (718) 661-1212.

NEW YORK SHIP AND BOAT MODEL FESTIVAL, an annual event that celebrates the traditional art of model-boat making, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 5 p.m. at the South Street Seaport, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan. The focus of the event is to allow the public and model makers to interact; model makers can exchange technical advice and talk about the stories behind the models. Activities include a workshop from 2 to 4 p.m. where youngsters can design a wooden ship and enter it in a competition. Events take place by Pier 16, underneath the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive canopy. Free, except for a $5 materials fee for the workshop. Information: (212) 748-8600.

''STORYTELLING IN THE GALLERIES: MAGIC IN EGYPT.'' Children will explore myths that were part of the daily lives of ancient Egyptians, tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the Egyptian Galleries of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''U.F.O (UNLIMITED FLYING OBJECTS).'' Lepidoptera (butterflies and moths) are the main attraction tomorrow and Sunday at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. From noon to 4 p.m. both days youngsters can make butterfly-inspired kites . Free: $2 plus museum admission. And at 1, 2 and 3 p.m., an entomologist from the Staten Island Zoo will talk abut the world of butterflies and bugs and take youngsters on a tour of anthropods' favorite haunts and habitats. Free with museum admission: $4; under 2 and members, free. For all ages. Information: (718) 273-2060.
Exhibitions

''FROM TENT TO TEMPLE: LIFE IN THE ANCIENT NEAR EAST,'' an interactive exhibition (through Jan. 14) developed by the Jewish Children's Learning Lab, Center for Jewish History, Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 294-8330, recreates the world of the Hebrews and other peoples of 3,900 to 2,900 years ago. The exhibition will be the setting for a storytelling and architecture workshop for children 5 to 12, Sunday from 2:30 to 3:45 p.m., commemorating the destruction of the temple on Tisha b'Av. Children will build their own model of the temple. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free with admission: $6; the elderly and ages 5 to 12, $4; under 5 and members, free.

''REPTILES: REAL AND ROBOTIC,'' including an alligator-snapping turtle 10 times life size and a Western diamondback rattlesnake 36 feet long, are part of the exhibition and related programs (through Sept. 17) at Science Playground at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Although those animals are robots, the real ones are no less impressive, including gila monsters, bearded dragons and blue-tongued skinks. Related activities include demonstrations, crafts workshops (there is a $1 materials fee) and on Saturdays at 2 p.m., (through Aug. 26), a special 45-minute presentation with a herpetologist for $2. Hours: Mondays from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7.50; $5 for ages 4 to 17 and the elderly; free for ages children 3 and under. Information: (718) 699-0005.
Zoos

''EXPEDITION AFRICA.'' Africa's rare cichlid fish, along with its penguins, frogs, lungfish and Red Sea corals, will be the focus of activities tomorrow and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the New York Aquarium, West Eighth Street and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, Brooklyn. There will also be performances, face painting, arts and crafts and a short film about Red Sea corals. Summer hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Admission: $9.75; the elderly and children 2 to 12, $6; under 2, free. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 265-3474.
